title: 1-2-3-4 Nostalgia
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/d57ffb8a29.7110eda4d0.NUpmQS.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
What are the last two digits of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{1234}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Source: Loren C. Larson, Problem-Solving Through Problems, Problem no. 3.2.3 (without modification)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is a part of the set Along Came A Spider.."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{1234}\\=9^{617}\\=(10-1)^{617}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using binomial expansion,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10-1)^{617}=\binom{617}{0}10^{617}-\binom{617}{1}10^{616}+...-\binom{617}{615}10^{2}+\binom{617}{616}10-\binom{617}{617}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=100k+6170-1=100\alpha+69"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{1234}\equiv 69\mod 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the last two digits are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{69}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice. Can we use binomial expansion for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{1234}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"? We have already considered this solution (before we posted ours, when we were discussing various approaches), and decided to not post it, because, we could not stand this procedure for other cases; in short, we could not generalize. Can you help?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{1234}=49^{617}\\=(50-1)^{617}\\\binom{617}{0}50^{617}-\binom{617}{1}50^{616}+...+\binom{617}{616}50-\binom{617}{617}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=617×50-1\\=3084"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So last two digits would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{84}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I can't generalize it, but this can be used for almost every number I can think of right now."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you give me an example of such number?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Thanks. There are infinite examples. Are you asking for a typical exponential representation such as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123^{456}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Sheikh Asif Imran Shouborno – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Square up 123 and it would become "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10k-1)^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Follow the same process!"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I mean an example where such manipulation won't work "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^0 = 1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^1 = 3 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^2 = 9 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^3 = 27 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^4 = 81 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^5 = 243 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^6 = 729 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^7 = 2187 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^8 = 6561 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^9 = 19683 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^10 = 59049"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^11 = 177147 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^12 = 531441 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^13 = 1594323"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^14 = 4782969"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^15 = 14348907 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^16 = 43046721"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^17 = 129140163"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^18 = 387420489"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^19 = 1162261467"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^20 = 3486784401 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^21 = 10460353203"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^22 = 31381059609 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^23 = 94143178827 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^24 = 282429536481 
."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notice how the pattern of the last two digits repeats from the power 20. If you take 1234/20 you get 14 as a remainder, so: 
3^1234 will have the same last 2 digits as 3^14 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence the answer is 69"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Euler's Theorem","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (A little advanced approach for an elementary problem):"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We will use 
"},{"type":"text","text":"Euler's totient function","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" to count how many integers are relatively prime to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\phi (100) =\phi (2^25^2)= 100(1-\frac12)(1-\frac15)=40"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, Euler's theorem implies that, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{40}\equiv 1\; (mod\; 100)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{1234}\equiv (3^{40})^{30}(3^{34})\equiv (3^{40-6})\; (mod\; 100)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, our duty is curbed down to find the inverse of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^6\equiv (27)^2 \equiv 29 \;(mod \; 100)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The inverse, my friends, is easily found to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{69}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The last step is left as a homework."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If a number has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\textit{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  terminal "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\textit{zeros} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then it contains "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\textit{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". But since  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10=5\cdot 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we are asking how many how many factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are there. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is smaller than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", for any factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" there will be enough factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to make a factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". thus we need to count only factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1239 \div 5 = 247.8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"247"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1239"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But the numbers divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"25"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we have counted."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1239 \div 25 = 49.56"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"49"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" again "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, there will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"125"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1239"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we have counted "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1239 \div 125 = 9.912"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" again "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"similarly there will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factor again of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" taking into consideration "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"625"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which contain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, there are total "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 247+49+9+1 = 306 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"which implies that there are total "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"306"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" zeros "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" at the end of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1239!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1, 2, 3 Again
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(x) = \\dfrac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the function above, what is the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\displaystyle \\lim_{x \\to \\infty}  f(x) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(x) = \dfrac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)^2} = \dfrac{x^2 - 4x +3}{x^2 - 4x +4} = 1 - \dfrac{1}{x^2 - 4x +4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As expanded above, when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" approaches infinity, the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{1}{x^2 - 4x +4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will reach "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and as shown in the graph below, the limit of this function is, therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/EGM4YWkOGA-point-of-asymptotes.JPG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Exactly. I just had a similar problem "},{"type":"text","text":"1, 2, 3, Go!","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", so I thought I'd just reuse it for a new topic. ;)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Or you just divide numerator and denominator by the highest power in the denominator.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 1,2,3...Distribute!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The total number of ways in which 5 balls of different colors can be distributed among 3 persons so that each person gets at least one ball is"}]}]}

title: 1 2 3 Go
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt{\left( \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{100} (101-i)x_{i}\right) + 1 } + \sqrt{\left( \displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{100} jx_{j} \right) + 2 } + \sqrt{\left( \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^{100} 101x_{k}\right ) + 3 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{100} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are  100 positive reals such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x_{1} + x_{2} + x_{3} + \cdots + x_{100} = 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find the maximum value of the expression above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let it be of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a\sqrt{b} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" b "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is square free and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a,b \in \mathbb{N} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Enter "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (a+b) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as your answer. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is an original problem"}]}]}

title: 123 go
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the number of intersection of diagonals in a 123-sided regular polygon."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clarification","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": if 2 intersections coincide with each other then both of                   them are to be considered."}]}]}

title: 1, 2, 3, Go!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(x) = \\dfrac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)^2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Considering the function above, what is the intersection point of the graph's asymptotes?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" f(x) = \dfrac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)^2} = \dfrac{x^2 - 4x +3}{x^2 - 4x +4} = 1 - \dfrac{1}{x^2 - 4x +4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/GPjoGjUPsq-point-of-asymptotes.JPG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the graph above, this function (red) is hyperbolic with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (blue) as its vertical asymptote, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can't equal to 2. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also, if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = 1, then 0 = - "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{1}{x^2 - 4x +4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can only approach "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" once "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" reaches +/- infinity. Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (green) is the graph's horizontal asymptote."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, these two asymptotes will intersect each other at the coordinates "},{"type":"text","text":"(2 , 1)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Power loss in conductors
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What’s the conductor power loss in watts for a 10AWG conductor that has a voltage drop of 3 percent in a 240V circuit, and carries a current flow of 24A?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I=24A"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E=240V x 3%"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E=240V x 0.03"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E= 7.20V"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The formula is P= I x E"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"24A x 7.20V = 172.80W"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1, 2, 3... Probability!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Aporia","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" published a difficult problem. Her problem was so difficult that it remained unsolved after many people had attempted it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When the first solver eventually occurred, the percentage of people getting her problem right showed as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1% of people got this right. (1 solver)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then, the next person to attempt her problem solved it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2% of people got this right. (2 solvers)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Surprisingly, the next person to attempt her problem also solved it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3% of people got this right. (3 solvers)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Despite the difficulty of Aporia's problem, 3 consecutive attempts by 3 different people were all successful."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Tyche","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" had also published her own difficult problem which remained unsolved after many attempts, and (as if it were fate) eventually saw the same progression for the percentage of people getting her problem right in 3 consecutive successful attempts."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1% of people got this right. (1 solver)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
  
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2% of people got this right. (2 solvers)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
  
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3% of people got this right. (3 solvers)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What an amazing turn of fortune!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Question","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Considering that all percentages shown are rounded to the nearest whole number (eg: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0.5\% \rightarrow 1\%"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"); What is the probability that "},{"type":"text","text":"Aporia","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"text","text":"Tyche","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" each had the same number of people "},{"type":"text","text":"attempt","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" their problem at the point that they each had 3 solvers?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In order to solve this problem, first we need to establish how many different ways there are of people attempting a single problem to produce 1%, 2%, and 3% of people getting the answer right in 3 consecutive successful attempts with the percentages rounded to the nearest whole number."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1%","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (Rounding to the nearest whole number)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The lowest number of people attempting a problem to produce 1% with 1 solver is "},{"type":"text","text":"67","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{1}{67} = 1.492 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The highest number of people attempting a problem to produce 1% with 1 solver is "},{"type":"text","text":"200","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{1}{200} = 0.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2%","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (Rounding to the nearest whole number)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The lowest number of people attempting a problem to produce 2% with 2 solvers is "},{"type":"text","text":"81","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{2}{81} = 2.46"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The highest number of people attempting a problem to produce 2% with 2 solvers is "},{"type":"text","text":"133","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{2}{133} = 1.503"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3%","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" (Rounding to the nearest whole number)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The lowest number of people attempting a problem to produce 3% with 3 solvers is "},{"type":"text","text":"86","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{3}{86} = 3.48"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The highest number of people attempting a problem to produce 3% with 3 solvers is "},{"type":"text","text":"120","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100 \times \dfrac{3}{120} = 2.5"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Ranges","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1% [67, 200]"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2% [81, 133]"}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3% [86, 120]"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"With each progressive range being a subset comfortably inside the previous percentages range, we can conclude that the number of ways to get 1%, 2%, 3% in 3 consecutive successful attempts is the size of the final range [86, 120] = "},{"type":"text","text":"35","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"120 - 86 + 1 = 35"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is important to check how the ranges compare with each other on problems like this, because the ranges may not necessarily overlap (or overlap enough). In which case, the number of outcomes could be smaller than the final range."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Probability","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now that we've established that there are 35 ways to create 1%, 2%, 3% with 3 consecutive successful attempts on a single problem, we can determine by the Rule of Product (because they are independent events) that there are 1225 combinations of outcomes for the number of people attempting the problem by Aporia and the number of people attempting the problem by Tyche (ie: 86|86, 86|87, 86|88, ... , 120|118, 120|119, 120|120).
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \dfrac{1}{35} \times \dfrac{1}{35} = \dfrac{1}{1225}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"35 of the 1225 outcomes are outcomes where the number of people that attempted each problem is the same (ie: 86|86, 87|87, 88|88, ..., etc.), so the probability of Aporia and Tyche having the same number of people attempt their problem after 3 consecutive successful attempts is 1/35."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large 35 \times \dfrac{1}{1225} = 35 \times \dfrac{1}{35} \times \dfrac{1}{35} = \huge\boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1, 2, 3 Tiling

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5 ways
(IIII, =II, I=I, II=, ==)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8 ways for 5"x2""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(IIIII, =III, I=II, II=I, III=, ==I, =I=, I==)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13 ways for 6"x2""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(IIIIII, =IIII, I=III, II=II, III=I, IIIII=, ==II, =I=I, =II=, I==I, I=I=, II==, ====)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"21 ways for 7"x2""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(IIIIIII, =IIIII, I=IIII, II=III, III=II, IIII=I, IIIII=,  ==III , =I=II , =II=I , =III=, I==II , I=I=I , I=II= , II==I , II=I= , III== , ===I , ==I=, =I==, I===)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21... it look like the Fibonacci sequence, isn’t it?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Calvin Lin – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I get what you are saying. Gotta love the Fibonacci sequence... and Phi too! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Scott Schwartz – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Yes, Steven is right in saying that there is 1 way to tile a "0 X 2" space, in order for our combinatorial identities to make sense."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For example, if the number of ways that you can tile a "0X2" space is 0, then the number of ways to tile a "0X2" space and then a "1X2" space is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 \times 1 = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" by the rule of product."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: In a similar manner, the empty product is defined as 1. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Jerith Jade – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I think Steven may be on to something. For me it relates to the definition of factorial. I always had a hard time understanding why 0! was 1. But it was explained to me that you can think about factorial as the number of ways you can arrange that number of things in a group. So you can arrange 3 thinks 6 ways, 2 things 2 ways, 1 think 1 way and 0 things 1 way. Also when you look at the definition of tiling: "a way of arranging identical plane shapes so that they completely cover an area without overlapping." Having no dominoes certainly would not tile a 2 dimensional shape and since there is no way of tiling the 1 dimensional shape there is only 1 way to do it and that's not to do it. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Not true. There are 0 ways to map that. Saying that there is a way (by not adding a domino) would alter all of the other sequences, as you would have to map no domino for each domino placed... Doubling the original answers. Nice idea, but the mathematics don't add up ;)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            But theres only 1 way to tile a 0x2 space

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is like the fibonacci sequence but starting from one.
Given a 2xN area, you can place two horizontal pieces and have all the ways fot the area 2x(N-2) or place one vertical piece and have the ways for an area of 2x(N-1), we get the recurrence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n = S_{n-2} + S_{n-1}, S_0 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and this means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n = F_{n+1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F_n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the n-th fibonacci number."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            They've already demonstrated in the example (setting up 3" x 2" area using 1" x 2" tiles) that the order does matter. According to that example, |= and =| are different, so surely ||= and =|| should also be different. I don't know if this is completely correct, but that's my take on this..

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We could place the first tile horizontally, which forces us to place another directly below it and so the empty area is now a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to tile this."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We could place the first tile vertically, so the empty area is now a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to tile this."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#20A900}{\boxed{5}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to tile a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In general, the number of ways to tile a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area is the sum of the number of ways to tile a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times (n-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"+"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the number of ways to tile a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2\times (n-2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area because we can apply this same process. This is, of course, equivalent to the "},{"type":"text","text":"Fibonacci sequence","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Observe that it is impossible to tile an odd number of vertical "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dominoes in a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an even number, and also it is impossible to place an even number of vertical "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dominoes in a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an odd number."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area to tile, there are 3 general cases according to the observation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Putting 4 vertical dominoes, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{4 \choose 4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to do it."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Putting 2 vertical dominoes, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{3 \choose 2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to do it. The other horizontal domino counted as 1 box hence we have 3 boxes to place with the vertical dominoes. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Putting 0 vertical dominoes, then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{2 \choose 0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to do it. We have only 2 boxes to place horizontal dominoes as there are zero vertical dominoes."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum all of the ways, then there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{4\choose4}+{3\choose2}+{2\choose0}=1+3+1=\boxed{5}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways to do it. The general summation we've been looking for many ways "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" area to be tiled with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\times2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" dominoes is:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\rfloor} {{n-i}\choose{n-2i}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For every "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" it may refer to fibonacci's sequence."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
